important_phrase: Refineries continued to invest in storage capacity to accommodate increased crude oil inventories flowing to the Gulf Coast from the Cushing, Oklahoma hub
Commercial real estate contacts witnessed continued improvement in demand and increased construction activity
Stffing agencies noted that job placements were up modestly, while the flow from temporary to permanent employment rose slightly
Applications for new home purchases made up a larger percentage of total mortgage applications as refinancing activity slowed
Intermodal traffic remained robust
Absorption rates remained positive
District reports on tourism and business travel remained positive
Contacts in the retail sector report either slight declines in sales or modest increases
Of the firms reporting revenue increases from a year ago, two had very slow growth
Office leasing activity is also down in Providence, while at the same time Rhode Island's industrial leasing market is tightening amid strong demand and limited inventory
Retail contacts report year-over-year same-store sales growth ranging from small single-digit decreases to low single-digit increases
The District's corn and soybean crops made up ground after a late start to planting as favorable weather helped plants emerge more quickly than the five-year average
Cost pressures increased some, but remained modest
Cost pressures increased, but remained modest
Credit conditions improved moderately from the prior reporting period
Demand for heavy and medium duty trucks grew moderately, as transportation volumes rose
Nonetheless, home sales declined modestly over the reporting period, while rents and prices were somewhat higher
Reports were mixed, but in most cases, retail sales met or fell slightly below expectations
Wllhead prices for natural gas have declined slightly, while oil prices were steady
New orders and production at District factories grew slowly
Demand for business credit increased, but at a slower pace than earlier in the second quarter
Existing-home prices are trending slowly higher
Pasture conditions improved and cattle prices continued to set new historical highs
Prices were unchanged or increased modestly at most responding firms, and employment held steady or rose slightly
Employment levels held steady or increased modestly and some contacts noted continued difficulty in finding skilled workers
Loan demand grew at a slightly slower pace compared to the previous reporting period
Construction-related manufacturers said demand was stable or rose slightly
Office investment activity picked up in Dallas but slowed in Houston
Contacts noted slightly stronger growth than the previous reporting period, and demand was above year-ago levels
Business activity held steady, drilling increased slightly, and expectations for the coming months strengthened further
The Tenth District economy expanded modestly in late May and June, and most contacts anticipated stronger growth in the months ahead
Prices grew at a slightly slower pace in most industries, and wage pressures were modest
Bankers reported steady overall loan demand, improved loan quality, and a slight increase in deposit levels
District manufacturing activity expanded modestly, although the pace of growth slowed somewhat compared to the previous survey period
Residential home sales expanded modestly, particularly for low- and medium-priced homes which continued to outsell higher-priced homes
Restaurant sales increased slightly, with sales remaining considerably higher than a year ago
Activity in the energy sector remained strong, while mining was steady
The Ninth District economy grew moderately since the last report
Wge increases were generally modest
Activity at professional business services firms increased since mid-May
Residential construction decreased from last year
Consumer spending increased modestly on net
Despite late planting in many areas, most fall crops were reported in good or better condition, and expectations of strong production this year lowered crop prices
Overall consumer spending increased in every District
New York and Chicago reported upward pressure on costs; Richmond and Kansas City reported that prices of raw materials and finished goods rose at a slightly slower pace
Overall, banking conditions improved slightly from the previous reporting period
Conditions in the staffing services industry across the Districts were unchanged or improved modestly compared with the previous survey period
Home prices continued to rise across most of the Districts, especially within urban areas, but contacts in the San Francisco District noted a slightly slower pace of home price appreciation

Most Districts reported modest retail sales growth since the last report, with slightly slower sales growth in the Boston and Atlanta Districts and faster sales growth in the New York, Dallas, and San Francisco Districts
Prices of finished goods and services continue to be stable, and businesses report moderate upward pressure on input prices
Overall, more than 35 percent of respondents say delinquency rates have declined, while fewer than 5 percent say they have increased

A major New York City employment agency reports that hiring activity has continued to advance gradually--hiring in the financial sector has slowed slightly, though this contact notes that there continues to be strong demand for IT workers and growing demand for human resource professionals
New York City's co-op and condo market remains robust, with prices up moderately from a year ago in Manhattan and Brooklyn
Tourism activity has generally been increasingly robust since the last report
Lending volumes continued to grow slowly over this period, and credit quality continued to improve
Brokers reported slight, steady overall increases in home prices
Home equity lines also grew, but gains were slower due to ongoing payoffs of prior balances by more cautious borrowers
A little over half of all firms reported increases of new orders and of sales
Residential real estate brokers reported slight improvements in sales in June
Dealers repeated their emphasis on staying lean, with cautious incremental hiring, which is helping to generate ongoing profitability
Natural gas output increased slightly in the past six weeks, while prices were unchanged
Wile shipments increased at a slower pace, the volume of new orders rose slightly
Employment increased at a moderate pace in recent weeks
Reports on consumer borrowing varied in recent weeks, while commercial lending improved
Manufacturing conditions improved on balance in recent weeks
The District's housing market improved modestly since the last report
Retail sales growth slowed since our last report
Contacts expressed ongoing concerns about water costs and availability
Manufacturing activity improved
Price inflation overall remained quite modest, although the pace of food and energy price increases appeared to pick up
In most areas, business loan demand increased only slightly and remains relatively weak
Defense-related manufacturers indicated that capacity utilization rates declined and the pace of new orders slowed further
Private-sector commercial construction activity increased modestly in most areas but more robustly in the San Francisco Bay Area and Southern California
Sales of low-end and mid-range technology goods were strong, offsetting relatively weak sales of premium devices
Over 90 percent of the District's corn, cotton, rice, sorghum, and soybean crops were rated in fair or better condition
Finally, wage and employment levels have grown modestly, while prices have increased slightly
Contacts in Little Rock and Louisville noted that wages are rising moderately for positions where the employment supply is limited
Total loans outstanding at a sample of small and mid-sized District banks increased , percent from mid-March to mid-June
Contacts in Louisville reported that more restaurants are opening than are closing and that a major grocer expanded floor space
Commercial and industrial construction activity improved throughout most of the District
One major mall in the District saw slightly positive sales growth
